frameDefinitions: Under some Condition, usually left implicit, a Duty needs to be fulfilled by a  Responsible_party.
This frame concerns an Evaluee being judged for its quality, i.e. how much it would probably be liked.
In this frame an Action is evaluated with respect to how fairly, justly or equitably the Action affects the Affected_party.
This frame contains adjectives and nouns that describe the truth or sincerity of communication.
This frame concerns a Cognizer's certainty about the correctness of beliefs  or expectations.
A Questioner asks a Witness (or defendant) questions in the context of a court procedure.
frameExamples: It would <t>behoove</t> us to comprehend and personalize what Jesus had to tell his disciples
Smithers was being very <t>fair</t> about the distribution of supplies.
Evelyn was <t>candid</t> with me about the party.
Lermontov was <t>certain</t> he would come to the party.
We 'd like to <t>cross-examine</t> the witness if we can.
listRoleDefinitions: The action that the <fen>Responsible_party</fen> is obligated to perform.
The person who must perform the <fen>Duty</fen>.
The time interval during which the <fen>Duty</fen> is mandatory.
A location in which the <fen>Duty</fen>  obtains.
The <fen>Evaluee</fen> is being judged for its quality.
This role marks expressions that denote a scalar property of the <fen>Evaluee</fen> with respect to which the <fen>Evaluee</fen> is judged.
The <fen>Actor</fen> is the individual who performs the <fen>Action</fen> and can thus be characterized with repsect to how that <fen>Action</fen> affects the <fen>Affected_party</fen>.
The <fen>Action</fen> is judged based on how just and appopriate it is to the <fen>Affected_party</fen> in a particular situation.
The <fen>Grounds</fen> is the event or state that requires some decision or action in response to it for which the <fen>Actor</fen> is judged.
The <fen>Affected_party</fen>'s treatment is what determines the evaluation of the <fen>Actor</fen>'s <fen>Action</fen>.

The <fen>Speaker</fen> produces the <fen>Message</fen>, the truth or sincerity of which is at issue. It is normally expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of the <t>target</t> word, or as the Nominal Head of prenominal uses.

<fen>Message</fen> is the communicative content whose truth or sincerity is at issue. This role does not normally co-occur with the other FEs in this frame. When it does occur, it is normally the External Argument of a predicative use of the <t>Target</t> word, or the modified Nominal Head in a prenominal use.

The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It often occurs without the <fen>Message</fen> role in predicative uses of the <t>target</t> word. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about'.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical or abstract setting in which the <fen>Message</fen> is conveyed.
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> is the person whose certainty or uncertainty is at issue.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the entity that a <fen>Cognizer</fen> has a certain/uncertain belief about.
The <fen>Content</fen> denotes the mental content that the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is certain or uncertain about.
The <fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part or action by a body part that conveys the mental state of  the <fen>Cognizer</fen>.
The individual who asks a <fen>Witness</fen> questions.
A person who is present in a courtroom in order to give some form of evidence, has been sworn in, and is being examined by a <fen>Questioner</fen>.
When the examination occurs.
Where the examination takes place.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Getting a shot against yellow fever</fex> is obligatory for travellers to Benin.
The use of TM software is obligatory <fex>for every freelance translator working on projects for our company</fex>.
<fex>These days</fex>, wearing a seat-belt is mandatory.
Gymnasium is not obligatory <fex>in Sweden</fex>, but nearly everyone attends gymnasium
The Beaujolais Nouveau is dazzling <fex>in freshness</fex>.
Evelyn made some candid remarks <fex>in French</fex>.
<fex>Marcel</fex> was sure that she had seen Eldridge on the balcony.
She talked of quests , of finding this absurd religious character , but he was unsure <fex>of her conviction</fex>.
I am sure <fex>that we'll arrive on time</fex>.
She caught sight of her mother's dubious <fex>expression</fex>.
You have leave to examine <fex>the witness.</fex>
